text: so sleep paralysis something that
actually very common many people have it
I've had it myself and what happens is
when you're in that REM stage of sleep
your body your brain is very active
you're dreaming the most during that
stage your mind your eyes are moving
there's a lot that's going on it's like
fireworks going on in your brain now
what happens in the rest of your body
and this is an evolutionary function is
that your body has muscle atonia meaning
your muscles are basically turned off
they can't work so your brain is active
your muscles can't work now for what
happens in sleep paralysis is that some
patients and we'll notice this early in
the morning because you're having more
REM sleep then will wake up in the
middle of REM sleep so I know myself I
woke up once in the middle of REM sleep
and I couldn't move my muscles and it
was very scary and it's scary for anyone
who has it because your mind is very
active your eyes are active but nothing
else is moving so you have to give
yourself a little while you'll come out
of the REM State your muscles will
awaken and it's fine it's a totally
normal thing to have now it can be um
indicative sometimes of other Sleep
Disorders so we'll see it a lot in
narcolepsy so some patients will report
that they have sleep paralysis if we see
sleep paralysis alone and nothing else
we don't really think all that much of
it but if we see other symptoms then it
might be a red flag for something else
that's going
on so in rem behavior disorder RBD it's
a newer diagnosis I'd say probably about
the past 10 to 15 years where really
recognizing it more and more patients
will come to our our practice and
they'll say I'm I'm waking up in the
morning and my I have bruises on my arms
my fists are bloody or they'll say you
know I my house was a mess I found
things all over the place generally that
can be sleepwalking but sleepwalking
tends to not be as violent and that's
earlier in the night when you're in the
deeper stages of sleep in RBD it tends
to be a bit more violent a bit more
aggressive so when you're in REM sleep
your muscles are supposed to be heav a
and no no function for them but for some
patients their muscles don't turn off so
if they're having a nightmare or very
Vivid dream they'll actually act out
essentially their dream in their sleep
during REM sleep so that's why we'll
start to see we'll see patients come in
with bruises their beds a mess they
might fall out of bed things like that
so it can be for some patients a very
violent problem that we actually need to
treat um
aggressively yeah there are some that
are run behavior disorder we'll see for
some Court documented cases you know and
they really need to have a thorough
valuation with a sleep specialist you
can't just say oh I was I was while I
was sleeping um there's confusional
arousal so there are states and deeper
sleep that can happen where people will
go and they'll disappear or they'll
they'll take on some other persona they
commit some crime but it's all when
they're in a very deep stage of sleep so
you really need to have a very thorough
evaluation but yes there is there's a
line of work of people who work with um
people who've been charged for crimes
and we'll actually do uh sleep sort of
analyses with
them
